questions.questionText: How many beats does a half note receive in 4/4 time?
questions.hint: A half note lasts twice as long as a quarter note.
questions.explanation: A half note receives two beats in common time (4/4).

questions.questionText: Which symbol represents a sharp note?
questions.hint: A sharp raises a note by one semitone.
questions.explanation: The sharp symbol (#) raises the pitch of a note by a half step.

questions.questionText: Which of these notes is a flat?
questions.hint: A flat lowers a note by one semitone.
questions.explanation: A flat (♭) lowers the pitch of a note by a half step.

questions.questionText: Which note is enharmonically equivalent to G♯?
questions.hint: Enharmonic equivalents sound the same but are written differently.
questions.explanation: G# and A♭ sound the same but are written differently in notation.

questions.questionText: Which note is highlighted on the keyboard?
questions.hint: This is the white key to the left of two black keys.
questions.explanation: Middle C is located just to the left of the set of two black keys on the keyboard.

questions.questionText: How many beats does a dotted half note receive in 4/4 time?
questions.hint: A dot adds half the original note’s value.
questions.explanation: A dotted half note lasts for three beats because the dot adds half of its original two beats.

questions.questionText: Which note is on the third line of the treble clef?
questions.hint: The treble clef line notes spell EGBDF.
questions.explanation: The third line in the treble clef represents the note B.

questions.questionText: Which of these notes is NOT in the C major scale?
questions.hint: C major has no sharps or flats.
questions.explanation: The C major scale consists of C, D, E, F, G, A, and B. It does not contain F#.

questions.questionText: Which of these notes lasts the longest?
questions.hint: This note lasts for four beats in 4/4 time.
questions.explanation: A whole note lasts for four beats, making it the longest note value in common time.

questions.questionText: Which of these notes is enharmonically equivalent to C#?
questions.hint: This note sounds the same but is spelled differently.
questions.explanation: C# and D♭ are enharmonic equivalents, meaning they sound the same but are spelled differently.
